item.description: A few months ago I found an intersting youtube video explaining why we have $$\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} n = \frac{-1}{12}$$ . Wait …. is it possible that the sum of positive number to equal to: a negative value ? 😲 a fractional number ? 😵 I don’t think so, but let’s dig into this. Here is the video I’m talking about: Okay … so let’s compute $$ \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} n $$ 1st approcah: how you are supposed to compute it $$ \begin{align} \sum_{n=1}^{x} n & = \left(\frac{x(x+1)}{2}\right) \newline \sum_{n=1}^\infty x & = \lim\limits_{x \to \infty} \dfrac{x(x+1))}{2} = \infty \end{align} $$
